docs.title: Welcome to tg-note Documentation
docs.text: **Intelligent Knowledge Base Builder**  Telegram bot that automatically transforms your messages, reposts, and articles into a structured knowledge base using AI agents.  [![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-yellow.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT) [![Python 3.11+](https://img.shields.io/badge/python-3.11+-blue.svg)](https://www.python.org/downloads/)  [Get Started](getting-started/quick-start.md){ .md-button .md-button--primary } [View on GitHub](https://github.com/ArtyomZemlyak/tg-note){ .md-button }

docs.title: What is tg-note?
docs.text:
tg-note is a Telegram bot that acts as your personal knowledge curator. It receives messages, reposts, and articles through Telegram, analyzes them using AI agent systems, and automatically saves the important information to your GitHub-based knowledge base in structured Markdown format.

Perfect for:

  • 📚 Building a personal knowledge base from Telegram channels
  • 🔬 Organizing research papers and scientific articles
  • 📰 Archiving news and insights from multiple sources
  • 🧠 Creating a searchable second brain

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• AI-Powered Analysis

    Intelligent content categorization and structuring using advanced agent systems

  • Automatic Markdown

    Converts any content into well-formatted Markdown files with proper structure

  • Smart Organization

    Automatic categorization by topics (AI, biology, physics, tech, etc.)

  • GitHub Integration

    Direct commits to your knowledge base repository with version control

  • Multi-User Support

    Each user can have their own personal knowledge base

  • Flexible Configuration

    Configure bot settings directly via Telegram commands

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get started with tg-note in just a few minutes:

1. Installation2. Configuration3. Run 
git clone https://github.com/ArtyomZemlyak/tg-note.git
cd tg-note
poetry install

# Copy configuration files
cp config.example.yaml config.yaml

# Add your Telegram bot token to .env
echo "TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN=your_token_here" > .env

poetry run python main.py

Full Installation Guide →

docs.title: Agent Types
docs.text: Choose the right agent for your needs:

docs.title: Qwen Code CLI (Recommended)
docs.text:
Uses Qwen Code CLI for advanced AI processing.

  • ✅ Full integration with Qwen3-Coder models
  • ✅ Automatic TODO planning
  • ✅ Built-in tools: web search, git, github, shell
  • ✅ Free tier: 2000 requests/day

Learn More →

docs.title: Qwen Code Agent
docs.text:
Pure Python agent with custom tools.

  • ✅ Python-native implementation
  • ✅ Flexible tool configuration
  • ✅ Custom TODO planning

Learn More →

docs.title: Stub Agent
docs.text:
Simple stub agent for testing and MVP.

  • ⚡ Fast and lightweight
  • 🔧 No external dependencies
  • 🧪 Perfect for testing

Learn More →

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Telegram Bot] --> B[Message Processor]
    B --> C[Agent System]
    C --> D[Knowledge Base Manager]
    D --> E[Git Operations]

    style A fill:#e1f5ff
    style C fill:#fff3e0
    style D fill:#f3e5f5
    style E fill:#e8f5e9

Detailed Architecture →

docs.title: Autonomous Agent Guide
docs.text: Understanding autonomous agent architecture.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Autonomous agents make their own decisions about which actions to take to accomplish goals.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Self-planning capability
  • Dynamic tool execution
  • Adaptive behavior

docs.title: See Also
docs.text: • Agent Overview

docs.title: Agent System Overview
docs.text: Understanding the AI agent system in tg-note.

docs.title: What are Agents?
docs.text: Agents are AI-powered systems that process your messages and transform them into structured knowledge base entries. They analyze content, categorize it, extract key information, and generate well-formatted Markdown files.

docs.title: Available Agents
docs.text: tg-note supports three types of agents, each with different capabilities and use cases.

docs.title: Comparison Table
docs.text: Feature Qwen Code CLI Qwen Code Stub AI Processing ✅ Advanced ✅ Good ❌ Basic Auto Planning ✅ Yes ⚠️ Limited ❌ No Web Search ✅ Built-in ✅ Custom ❌ No Git Operations ✅ Built-in ✅ Custom ❌ No External Dependencies Node.js None None Free Tier 2000/day API costs Free Best For Production Custom needs Testing/MVP

docs.title: 1. Qwen Code CLI ⭐ Recommended
docs.text: The most powerful agent using the official Qwen Code CLI tool.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• ✅ Advanced AI Processing - Qwen3-Coder models
  • ✅ Automatic Planning - Creates and executes TODO plans
  • ✅ Built-in Tools - Web search, Git, GitHub, Shell
  • ✅ Vision Support - Can analyze images
  • ✅ Free Tier - 2000 requests/day, 60 req/min

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Install Node.js 20+
npm install -g @qwen-code/qwen-code@latest

# Authenticate
qwen

# Configure
AGENT_TYPE: "qwen_code_cli"

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text:
• ✅ Production deployments
  • ✅ Need best quality output
  • ✅ Want automatic planning
  • ✅ Can install Node.js

Full Documentation →

docs.title: 2. Qwen Code Agent
docs.text: Pure Python agent with customizable tools.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• ✅ Python Native - No Node.js required
  • ✅ Custom Tools - Build your own tool integrations
  • ✅ Flexible - Full control over processing
  • ⚠️ API Costs - Requires Qwen API key

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
AGENT_TYPE: "qwen_code"
AGENT_MODEL: "qwen-max"

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text:
• ✅ Need Python-only solution
  • ✅ Custom tool requirements
  • ✅ Full control over agent behavior
  • ❌ Can't install Node.js

Full Documentation →

docs.title: 3. Stub Agent
docs.text: Simple testing agent without AI.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• ✅ Fast - No API calls
  • ✅ Simple - Basic categorization
  • ✅ No Dependencies - Works out of the box
  • ❌ Limited - No AI analysis

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: AGENT_TYPE: "stub"

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text:
• ✅ Testing and development
  • ✅ MVP/prototype
  • ✅ No API keys available
  • ❌ Production use

Full Documentation →

docs.title: Processing Pipeline
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Message] --> B[Agent]
    B --> C{Analyze}
    C --> D[Categorize]
    D --> E[Extract Info]
    E --> F[Generate Markdown]
    F --> G[Save to KB]

    style B fill:#fff3e0
    style F fill:#e8f5e9

docs.title: Agent Workflow
docs.text:
1. Receive Content
  2. Text messages
  3. URLs
  4. Forwarded posts

  5. Media

  6. Analyze

  7. Understand topic
  8. Extract key points

  9. Identify category

  10. Process

  11. Search for context (if enabled)
  12. Gather additional info

  13. Structure content

  14. Generate

  15. Create Markdown file
  16. Add metadata

  17. Format properly

  18. Save

  19. Write to KB
  20. Commit to Git
  21. Notify user

docs.title: Decision Tree
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Choose Agent] --> B{Can install Node.js?}
    B -->|Yes| C[Want best quality?]
    B -->|No| D{Need AI?}

    C -->|Yes| E[Qwen Code CLI ⭐]
    C -->|No| D

    D -->|Yes| F[Qwen Code]
    D -->|No| G[Stub Agent]

    style E fill:#c8e6c9
    style F fill:#fff9c4
    style G fill:#ffccbc

docs.title: For Production
docs.text:
→ Qwen Code CLI

  • Best quality results
  • Automatic planning
  • Built-in tools
  • Free tier available

docs.title: For Custom Needs
docs.text:
→ Qwen Code

  • Full Python control
  • Custom tool integration
  • Flexible configuration

docs.title: For Testing
docs.text:
→ Stub Agent

  • Quick setup
  • No dependencies
  • Fast iteration

docs.title: Global Settings
docs.text:
Set in config.yaml:

# Agent Selection
AGENT_TYPE: "qwen_code_cli"

# Common Settings
AGENT_MODEL: "qwen-max"
AGENT_TIMEOUT: 300

# Tool Permissions
AGENT_ENABLE_WEB_SEARCH: true
AGENT_ENABLE_GIT: true
AGENT_ENABLE_GITHUB: true
AGENT_ENABLE_SHELL: false

docs.title: Per-User Settings
docs.text:
Users can override via Telegram:

/agentsettings
# Or
/setsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT 600

docs.title: Content Analysis
docs.text:
All agents can: - Extract text content - Identify topics - Generate titles - Create metadata

Advanced agents (Qwen) add: - Deep semantic understanding - Context enrichment - Smart categorization - Quality summaries

docs.title: Tool Usage
docs.text: Tool Qwen CLI Qwen Code Stub Web Search ✅ ✅ ❌ Git Ops ✅ ✅ ❌ GitHub API ✅ ✅ ❌ Shell ✅ ⚠️ ❌ Vision ✅ ❌ ❌

docs.title: Typical Processing Time
docs.text: Agent Short Text Medium Text Long Text Qwen CLI 5-15s 15-45s 45-120s Qwen Code 3-10s 10-30s 30-90s Stub <1s <1s <1s

docs.title: Factors Affecting Speed
docs.text:
• Content length
  • URL complexity
  • Web search usage
  • API response time
  • Network latency

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Qwen Code CLI Guide
  • Qwen Code Agent Guide
  • Autonomous Agent Guide
  • Stub Agent Reference

docs.title: Qwen Code CLI Agent
docs.text: Complete guide to using the Qwen Code CLI agent.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Qwen Code CLI agent is the most powerful option, using the official qwen-code CLI tool for advanced AI processing.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• ✅ Full integration with Qwen3-Coder models
  • ✅ Automatic TODO planning
  • ✅ Built-in tools: web search, git, github, shell
  • ✅ Free tier: 2000 requests/day
  • ✅ Vision model support

docs.title: 1. Install Node.js 20+
docs.text:
# Ubuntu/Debian
curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_20.x | sudo -E bash -
sudo apt-get install -y nodejs

# macOS
brew install node@20

# Windows
# Download from nodejs.org

docs.title: 2. Install Qwen Code CLI
docs.text: npm install -g @qwen-code/qwen-code@latest

docs.title: 3. Verify Installation
docs.text: qwen --version

docs.title: 4. Authenticate
docs.text:
qwen

Follow the prompts to authenticate via qwen.ai.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Update config.yaml:

AGENT_TYPE: "qwen_code_cli"
AGENT_QWEN_CLI_PATH: "qwen"
AGENT_TIMEOUT: 300
AGENT_ENABLE_WEB_SEARCH: true
AGENT_ENABLE_GIT: true
AGENT_ENABLE_GITHUB: true
AGENT_ENABLE_SHELL: false

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Message received
  2. Agent prepares prompt
  3. Calls qwen CLI
  4. Qwen creates TODO plan
  5. Executes plan with tools
  6. Returns structured markdown
  7. Saved to KB

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Agent Overview
  • Qwen Code Agent

  • ✅ Flexible tool configuration

  • ✅ Web search, Git, GitHub support

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:

docs.title: Configuration Guide
docs.text: Complete guide to configuring tg-note.

docs.title: Configuration Sources
docs.text:
tg-note supports multiple configuration sources with the following priority (highest to lowest):

  1. Environment Variables - Highest priority
  2. .env file - For credentials and overrides
  3. config.yaml - Base configuration
  4. Default values - Built-in defaults

Best Practice

  • Store sensitive data (tokens, API keys) in .env
  • Store general settings in config.yaml
  • Use environment variables for deployment overrides

docs.title: config.yaml
docs.text:
Main configuration file for non-sensitive settings.

# Knowledge Base Settings
KB_PATH: ./knowledge_base
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: true
KB_GIT_REMOTE: origin
KB_GIT_BRANCH: main

# Agent Configuration
AGENT_TYPE: "qwen_code_cli"  # stub, qwen_code, qwen_code_cli
AGENT_MODEL: "qwen-max"
AGENT_TIMEOUT: 300
AGENT_ENABLE_WEB_SEARCH: true
AGENT_ENABLE_GIT: true
AGENT_ENABLE_GITHUB: true
AGENT_ENABLE_SHELL: false

# Processing Settings
MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT: 30
PROCESSED_LOG_PATH: ./data/processed.json

# Logging Settings
LOG_LEVEL: INFO  # DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, CRITICAL
LOG_FILE: ./logs/bot.log

# Security
ALLOWED_USER_IDS: ""  # Comma-separated, empty = all allowed

docs.title: .env File
docs.text:
Credentials and sensitive data (never commit to git!).

# Required
TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN=your_bot_token_here

# Optional API Keys
OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-...
ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-...
QWEN_API_KEY=your_qwen_key

# GitHub Integration
GITHUB_TOKEN=ghp_...

docs.title: KB_PATH
docs.text:
• Type: Path
  • Default: ./knowledge_base
  • Description: Path to your knowledge base directory
  • Example: /path/to/my-kb

docs.title: KB_GIT_ENABLED
docs.text:
• Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • Description: Enable Git operations
  • Example: true or false

docs.title: KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH
docs.text:
• Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • Description: Automatically push changes to remote
  • Example: true or false

docs.title: KB_GIT_REMOTE
docs.text:
• Type: String
  • Default: origin
  • Description: Git remote name
  • Example: origin

docs.title: KB_GIT_BRANCH
docs.text:
• Type: String
  • Default: main
  • Description: Git branch to use
  • Example: main or master

docs.title: AGENT_TYPE
docs.text:
• Type: String
  • Default: stub
  • Options: stub, qwen_code, qwen_code_cli
  • Description: Agent implementation to use
  • Recommendation: Use qwen_code_cli for production

docs.title: AGENT_MODEL
docs.text:
• Type: String
  • Default: qwen-max
  • Description: AI model to use
  • Examples: qwen-max, qwen-turbo, gpt-4

docs.title: AGENT_TIMEOUT
docs.text:
• Type: Integer (seconds)
  • Default: 300
  • Description: Maximum time for agent processing
  • Example: 600 (10 minutes)

docs.title: AGENT_ENABLE_WEB_SEARCH
docs.text:
• Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • Description: Allow web search capability
  • Example: true or false

docs.title: AGENT_ENABLE_GIT
docs.text:
• Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • Description: Allow Git operations
  • Example: true or false

docs.title: AGENT_ENABLE_GITHUB
docs.text:
• Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • Description: Allow GitHub API access
  • Example: true or false

docs.title: AGENT_ENABLE_SHELL
docs.text:
• Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • Description: Allow shell command execution
  • Warning: ⚠️ Security risk, use with caution
  • Example: false

docs.title: MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT
docs.text:
• Type: Integer (seconds)
  • Default: 30
  • Description: Wait time before processing grouped messages
  • Example: 60 (1 minute)

docs.title: PROCESSED_LOG_PATH
docs.text:
• Type: Path
  • Default: ./data/processed.json
  • Description: Path to processing tracker database
  • Example: ./data/tracker.json

docs.title: LOG_LEVEL
docs.text:
• Type: String
  • Default: INFO
  • Options: DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, CRITICAL
  • Description: Logging verbosity level
  • Example: DEBUG for development

docs.title: LOG_FILE
docs.text:
• Type: Path
  • Default: ./logs/bot.log
  • Description: Path to log file
  • Example: ./logs/tg-note.log

docs.title: TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN
docs.text:
• Type: String (Secret)
  • Required: Yes
  • Source: .env or environment variable only
  • Description: Telegram bot authentication token
  • Example: 1234567890:ABCdefGHIjklMNOpqrsTUVwxyz

docs.title: ALLOWED_USER_IDS
docs.text:
• Type: String (comma-separated)
  • Default: "" (all users allowed)
  • Description: Whitelist of allowed Telegram user IDs
  • Example: 12345678,87654321

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
config.yaml
# Development configuration
KB_PATH: ./dev-kb
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: false  # Manual push for dev

AGENT_TYPE: "stub"  # Fast testing
AGENT_TIMEOUT: 60

MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT: 10  # Quick testing

LOG_LEVEL: DEBUG
LOG_FILE: ./logs/dev.log

ALLOWED_USER_IDS: "your_user_id"  # Only you

docs.title: Production Setup
docs.text:
config.yaml
# Production configuration
KB_PATH: /var/kb/production
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: true
KB_GIT_REMOTE: origin
KB_GIT_BRANCH: main

AGENT_TYPE: "qwen_code_cli"
AGENT_MODEL: "qwen-max"
AGENT_TIMEOUT: 300
AGENT_ENABLE_WEB_SEARCH: true
AGENT_ENABLE_GIT: true
AGENT_ENABLE_GITHUB: true
AGENT_ENABLE_SHELL: false

MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT: 30
PROCESSED_LOG_PATH: /var/data/processed.json

LOG_LEVEL: INFO
LOG_FILE: /var/log/tg-note/bot.log

ALLOWED_USER_IDS: ""  # Allow all authenticated users

docs.title: Testing Setup
docs.text:
config.yaml
# Testing configuration
KB_PATH: ./test-kb
KB_GIT_ENABLED: false  # No git for tests

AGENT_TYPE: "stub"
AGENT_TIMEOUT: 30

MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT: 5

LOG_LEVEL: WARNING  # Reduce noise
LOG_FILE: ./logs/test.log

ALLOWED_USER_IDS: "123"  # Test user only

docs.title: Using Environment Variables
docs.text:
Override any setting using environment variables:

export MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT=120
export LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG
export AGENT_TYPE=qwen_code_cli

python main.py

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text:
ENV TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN=your_token
ENV KB_PATH=/app/kb
ENV LOG_LEVEL=INFO
ENV AGENT_TYPE=qwen_code_cli

docs.title: Check Current Configuration
docs.text: poetry run python -c "from config import settings; print(settings)"

docs.title: Validate Configuration
docs.text:
from config import settings

errors = settings.validate()
if errors:
    print(f"Configuration errors: {errors}")
else:
    print("Configuration is valid!")

docs.title: Setting Not Applied
docs.text:
Check the priority order:

  1. Environment variable set? → Takes precedence
  2. Value in .env? → Overrides config.yaml
  3. Value in config.yaml? → Uses this
  4. Falls back to default
# Check environment variable
echo $MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT

# Check .env file
cat .env | grep MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT

# Check config.yaml
cat config.yaml | grep MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT

docs.title: YAML Syntax Error
docs.text:
Validate YAML syntax:

python -c "import yaml; yaml.safe_load(open('config.yaml'))"

docs.title: Permission Issues
docs.text:
Check file permissions:

ls -la config.yaml .env
chmod 600 .env  # Secure credentials
chmod 644 config.yaml

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Installation Guide
  • Settings Management
  • Agent Configuration

docs.title: First Steps
docs.text: Your first steps with tg-note after installation.

docs.title: Create a Bot with BotFather
docs.text:
1. Open Telegram and search for @BotFather
  2. Start a chat and send /newbot
  3. Follow the prompts:
  4. Choose a name for your bot (e.g., "My Knowledge Bot")
  5. Choose a username (must end in "bot", e.g., "my_knowledge_bot")
  6. BotFather will give you a token - save it securely!

Example token format: 

1234567890:ABCdefGHIjklMNOpqrsTUVwxyz12345678

docs.title: Add Token to Configuration
docs.text:
Add your token to .env:

TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN=1234567890:ABCdefGHIjklMNOpqrsTUVwxyz12345678

docs.title: 2. Get Your User ID (Optional)
docs.text:
If you want to restrict bot access to only yourself:

  1. Open Telegram and search for @userinfobot
  2. Start a chat and send any message
  3. Bot will reply with your user info
  4. Copy your User ID

Add to config.yaml:

ALLOWED_USER_IDS: "123456789"  # Your user ID

docs.title: Option A: Local Knowledge Base
docs.text:
Create a new local Git repository:

mkdir my-knowledge-base
cd my-knowledge-base
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
cd ..

Update config.yaml:

KB_PATH: ./my-knowledge-base
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: false  # No remote yet

docs.title: Option B: GitHub Knowledge Base
docs.text:
1. Create a new repository on GitHub (e.g., my-kb)
  2. Clone it locally:
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/my-kb.git
  1. Update config.yaml:
KB_PATH: ./my-kb
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: true
KB_GIT_REMOTE: origin
KB_GIT_BRANCH: main

docs.title: 4. Start the Bot
docs.text:
poetry run python main.py

Expected output:

INFO - Starting tg-note bot...
INFO - Configuration validated successfully
INFO - Processing tracker initialized
INFO - Repository manager initialized
INFO - Telegram bot started successfully
INFO - Bot initialization completed
INFO - Press Ctrl+C to stop

docs.title: 5. Initialize Bot in Telegram
docs.text:
Open Telegram, find your bot, and send:

/start

Bot should reply with a welcome message!

docs.title: 6. Configure Knowledge Base in Telegram
docs.text:
Tell the bot where to save notes:

/setkb my-notes

Or use a GitHub repo:

/setkb https://github.com/yourusername/my-kb

docs.title: 7. Send Your First Message
docs.text:
Send or forward any message to the bot. Examples:

  • Plain text message
  • Forwarded message from a channel
  • Article link
  • Multiple messages

The bot will process and save it to your knowledge base!

docs.title: 8. Check Your Knowledge Base
docs.text:
Look in your KB directory:

ls -la my-knowledge-base/

You should see:

topics/
├── general/
│   └── 2025-10-03-your-first-note.md
└── index.md

docs.title: 9. Verify Git Commits
docs.text:
cd my-knowledge-base
git log --oneline

You should see automatic commits!

docs.title: 10. Explore Bot Commands
docs.text:
Try these commands:

/help      # Show all commands
/kb        # Show KB info
/status    # Show statistics
/settings  # Open settings menu

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Learn All Commands

    Master all bot commands and features

    Bot Commands

  • Upgrade Your Agent

    Install Qwen Code CLI for better AI processing

    Agent Setup

  • Customize Settings

    Configure bot behavior via Telegram

    Settings Guide

  • Organize Your KB

    Learn KB structure and organization

    KB Setup

docs.title: Bot Not Responding
docs.text:
1. Check if bot is running in terminal
  2. Verify bot token in .env
  3. Check logs: tail -f logs/bot.log

docs.title: "Not authorized" Error
docs.text:
• Wrong bot token
  • Check .env file
  • Restart the bot

docs.title: KB Not Created
docs.text:
• Check KB_PATH in config
  • Ensure directory exists
  • Check permissions

docs.title: Messages Not Saved
docs.text:
• Check logs for errors
  • Verify KB setup: /kb
  • Check Git status in KB folder

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
• 📖 Full Documentation
  • 🐛 Issue Tracker
  • 💬 Discussions

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: Detailed installation instructions for tg-note.

docs.title: Required
docs.text:
• Python 3.11 or higher
  • Poetry - Python dependency manager
  • Git - Version control system
  • Telegram Account - To create and use the bot

docs.title: Optional
docs.text:
• Node.js 20+ - Required for qwen_code_cli agent (recommended)
  • Docker - For containerized deployment

docs.title: Installation Methods
docs.text:
Local InstallationDocker Installation

Coming Soon

Docker support is planned for future releases.

For now, please use the local installation method.

docs.title: 1. Install Python 3.11+
docs.text:
Check your Python version:

python3 --version

If you need to install Python 3.11+:

Ubuntu/DebianmacOSWindows 
sudo apt update
sudo apt install python3.11 python3.11-venv python3-pip

brew install python@3.11

Download from python.org

docs.title: 2. Install Poetry
docs.text:
curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -

Or using pipx:

pipx install poetry

Add Poetry to your PATH (if needed):

export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"

docs.title: 3. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/ArtyomZemlyak/tg-note.git
cd tg-note

docs.title: 4. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
poetry install

This creates a virtual environment and installs all required packages.

docs.title: 5. Verify Installation
docs.text: poetry run python -c "from config import settings; print('Installation successful!')"

docs.title: Qwen Code CLI (Recommended for Production)
docs.text: The Qwen Code CLI agent provides the best AI-powered processing capabilities.

docs.title: 1. Install Node.js 20+
docs.text:
Ubuntu/DebianmacOSWindows 
curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_20.x | sudo -E bash -
sudo apt-get install -y nodejs

brew install node@20

Download from nodejs.org

docs.title: 2. Install Qwen Code CLI
docs.text: npm install -g @qwen-code/qwen-code@latest

docs.title: 3. Verify Installation
docs.text: qwen --version

docs.title: 4. Authenticate
docs.text:
qwen

Follow the interactive authentication process. You'll get:

  • 2000 free requests per day
  • 60 requests per minute
  • No token limits

Learn more about Qwen Code CLI →

docs.title: 1. Create Configuration Files
docs.text:
# Copy example configuration
cp config.example.yaml config.yaml

docs.title: 2. Setup Environment Variables
docs.text:
Create a .env file:

touch .env

Add your credentials:

# Required
TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN=your_bot_token_here

# Optional - For advanced features
OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_key
ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_anthropic_key

Security

Never commit your .env file to version control! It's already in .gitignore, but always double-check.

docs.title: 3. Configure Basic Settings
docs.text:
Edit config.yaml:

# Knowledge Base
KB_PATH: ./knowledge_base
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: true

# Agent Type
AGENT_TYPE: "stub"  # Change to "qwen_code_cli" if installed

# Logging
LOG_LEVEL: INFO
LOG_FILE: ./logs/bot.log

Full configuration guide →

docs.title: Run Tests
docs.text:
Verify everything is working:

# Run all tests
poetry run pytest

# Run with coverage
poetry run pytest --cov=src --cov-report=html

# Run specific test
poetry run pytest tests/test_tracker.py -v

docs.title: Check Configuration
docs.text: poetry run python -c "from config import settings; print(settings)"

docs.title: Test Bot Connection
docs.text:
poetry run python main.py

You should see:

INFO - Starting tg-note bot...
INFO - Configuration validated successfully
INFO - Bot initialization completed

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
After installation, your directory should look like:

tg-note/
├── config/              # Configuration modules
├── src/
│   ├── bot/            # Telegram bot
│   ├── processor/      # Message processing
│   ├── agents/         # AI agents
│   ├── knowledge_base/ # KB management
│   └── tracker/        # Processing tracker
├── tests/              # Unit tests
├── data/               # Created on first run
├── logs/               # Created on first run
├── config.yaml         # Your configuration
├── .env                # Your credentials
├── pyproject.toml      # Project metadata
├── poetry.lock         # Dependency lock file
└── main.py            # Entry point

docs.title: Updating
docs.text:
To update tg-note to the latest version:

git pull origin main
poetry install

To update dependencies:

poetry update

docs.title: Poetry Not Found
docs.text:
# Add to PATH
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"

# Make permanent
echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Python Version Issues
docs.text:
# Use specific Python version with Poetry
poetry env use python3.11

# Verify
poetry run python --version

docs.title: Permission Errors
docs.text:
# On Linux/macOS
sudo chown -R $USER:$USER ~/.local

# Or install without sudo
curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 - --user

docs.title: Virtual Environment Issues
docs.text:
# Remove and recreate
poetry env remove python
poetry install

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After successful installation:

  1. Configure the bot
  2. Get your Telegram bot token
  3. Run the bot
  4. Choose your agent

docs.title: Uninstallation
docs.text:
To completely remove tg-note:

# Remove virtual environment
poetry env remove python

# Remove project directory
cd ..
rm -rf tg-note

# Optionally remove Poetry
pipx uninstall poetry

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with tg-note in just a few minutes!

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have:

  • Python 3.11+ installed
  • Poetry (Python dependency manager)
  • Git installed
  • Telegram Account
  • Node.js 20+ (optional, for qwen_code_cli agent)

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/ArtyomZemlyak/tg-note.git
cd tg-note

docs.title: 2. Install Poetry
docs.text:
If you don't have Poetry installed:

curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -
# or using pipx:
# pipx install poetry

docs.title: 3. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
poetry install

This will automatically create a virtual environment and install all dependencies.

docs.title: 1. Create Configuration Files
docs.text:
# Copy example configuration
cp config.example.yaml config.yaml

docs.title: 2. Get Telegram Bot Token
docs.text:
1. Open @BotFather in Telegram
  2. Send /newbot and follow instructions
  3. Copy the token provided

docs.title: 3. Create .env File
docs.text:
Create a .env file with your credentials:

cat > .env << EOF
# Required: Telegram Bot Token
TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN=your_bot_token_here

# Optional: API keys for advanced agents
# OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_key
# ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_anthropic_key
EOF

docs.title: 4. Configure config.yaml
docs.text:
Edit config.yaml with your basic settings:

# Knowledge Base Settings
KB_PATH: ./knowledge_base
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: true
KB_GIT_REMOTE: origin
KB_GIT_BRANCH: main

# Agent Configuration
AGENT_TYPE: "stub"  # Options: stub, qwen_code, qwen_code_cli

# Processing Settings
MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT: 30  # seconds

# Logging
LOG_LEVEL: INFO
LOG_FILE: ./logs/bot.log

# User Access Control (empty = all users allowed)
ALLOWED_USER_IDS: ""

docs.title: Start the Bot
docs.text:
poetry run python main.py
# or activate the virtual environment first:
poetry shell
python main.py

You should see:

INFO - Starting tg-note bot...
INFO - Configuration validated successfully
INFO - Processing tracker initialized
INFO - Repository manager initialized
INFO - Telegram bot started successfully
INFO - Bot initialization completed
INFO - Press Ctrl+C to stop

docs.title: Configure Knowledge Base in Telegram
docs.text:
Open your bot in Telegram and:

/start                    # Initialize the bot
/setkb my-notes           # Create local knowledge base
# or
/setkb https://github.com/username/kb-repo  # Use GitHub repository

docs.title: Start Sending Messages!
docs.text: Just forward any message or write text - the bot will automatically process and save it to your knowledge base.

docs.title: Stop the Bot
docs.text: Press Ctrl+C in the terminal.

docs.title: Optional: Install Qwen Code CLI
docs.text:
For advanced AI processing, install the Qwen Code CLI agent:

# Install Node.js 20+ first, then:
npm install -g @qwen-code/qwen-code@latest

# Authenticate (2000 free requests/day)
qwen

# Update config.yaml
AGENT_TYPE: "qwen_code_cli"

Learn more about Qwen Code CLI →

docs.title: Basic Commands
docs.text:
Command Description Example /start Initialize bot interaction /start /help Display help information /help /setkb <name\|url> Setup knowledge base /setkb my-notes /kb Show current KB info /kb /status Display processing statistics /status /settings Open interactive settings menu /settings

Full command reference →

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you have tg-note running, explore these topics:

  • Configuration

    Learn about all configuration options

    Configuration Guide

  • User Guide

    Learn how to use all bot features

    User Guide

  • Agent System

    Understand AI agents and choose the right one

    Agent Overview

  • Knowledge Base

    Setup and manage your knowledge base

    KB Setup

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN is required

Add your bot token to the .env file

Not a git repository

Check KB_PATH in config.yaml - it should point to a git repository

ModuleNotFoundError

Activate the Poetry virtual environment: poetry shell

Tests not running

Install dependencies: poetry install

Full troubleshooting guide →

docs.text:
• 📖 Check the User Guide
  • 🐛 Report issues on GitHub
  • 💬 Ask questions in Discussions

docs.title: Bot Commands
docs.text: Complete reference for all tg-note bot commands.

docs.title: /start
docs.text:
Initialize interaction with the bot.

Usage: 

/start

Response: - Welcome message - Bot introduction - Quick start instructions

docs.title: /help
docs.text:
Display help information and available commands.

Usage: 

/help

Response: - List of all commands - Brief descriptions - Links to documentation

docs.title: /setkb
docs.text:
Setup or change your knowledge base location.

Usage: 

/setkb <name|url>

Examples:

# Local knowledge base
/setkb my-notes

# GitHub repository
/setkb https://github.com/username/kb-repo

# Private repo (configure auth separately)
/setkb https://github.com/username/private-kb

What it does: - Creates or connects to a knowledge base - Initializes Git if needed - Sets up directory structure

docs.title: /kb
docs.text:
Show current knowledge base information.

Usage: 

/kb

Response: - KB path - Git status - Number of files - Last commit info

docs.title: /status
docs.text:
Display processing statistics.

Usage: 

/status

Response: - Messages processed - Notes created - Success/failure rate - Agent type in use

docs.title: /settings
docs.text:
Open interactive settings menu.

Usage: 

/settings

Features: - Browse settings by category - Interactive inline keyboard - Quick toggles for boolean values - Detailed setting information

Categories: - 📚 Knowledge Base - 🤖 Agent Configuration - ⚙️ Processing - 📝 Logging

Learn more →

docs.title: /viewsettings
docs.text:
View all settings or filtered by category.

Usage: 

/viewsettings [category]

Examples:

# View all settings
/viewsettings

# View specific category
/viewsettings knowledge_base
/viewsettings agent
/viewsettings processing

Response: - Setting name - Current value - Default value - Description

docs.title: /setsetting
docs.text:
Change a specific setting value.

Usage: 

/setsetting <name> <value>

Examples:

# Boolean settings
/setsetting KB_GIT_ENABLED true
/setsetting KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH false

# Numeric settings
/setsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT 600
/setsetting MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT 60

# String settings
/setsetting AGENT_TYPE qwen_code_cli
/setsetting LOG_LEVEL DEBUG

Supported Types: - Boolean: true, false, 1, 0, yes, no - Integer: Any number - String: Any text - Path: File system paths

docs.title: /resetsetting
docs.text:
Reset a setting to its default value.

Usage: 

/resetsetting <name>

Examples:

/resetsetting KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH
/resetsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT
/resetsetting LOG_LEVEL

docs.title: /kbsettings
docs.text:
Quick access to Knowledge Base settings.

Usage: 

/kbsettings

Shows: - KB_PATH - KB_GIT_ENABLED - KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH - KB_GIT_REMOTE - KB_GIT_BRANCH

docs.title: /agentsettings
docs.text:
Quick access to Agent settings.

Usage: 

/agentsettings

Shows: - AGENT_TYPE - AGENT_MODEL - AGENT_TIMEOUT - AGENT_ENABLE_WEB_SEARCH - AGENT_ENABLE_GIT - AGENT_ENABLE_GITHUB

docs.title: Send Text Message
docs.text:
Simply send any text message to save it.

Example: 

This is an interesting article about AI...

Processing: 1. Message received 2. Analyzed by agent 3. Categorized automatically 4. Saved as Markdown 5. Committed to Git

docs.title: Forward Message
docs.text:
Forward messages from any chat or channel.

How: 1. Find message to save 2. Tap Forward 3. Select your tg-note bot

Supports: - Channel posts - Group messages - Media with captions - Links and URLs

docs.title: Send Multiple Messages
docs.text:
Send consecutive messages - they'll be grouped automatically.

Example: 

First message about a topic...
(Send)
Second message with more details...
(Send)
Third message with conclusion...

Processing: - Bot waits 30 seconds (configurable) - Groups related messages - Creates single note

docs.title: Send Links
docs.text:
Send article links for processing.

Example: 

https://arxiv.org/abs/12345

With Qwen Code CLI: - Fetches article content - Analyzes and summarizes - Extracts key information - Saves structured note

docs.title: Command Reference Table
docs.text: Command Arguments Description Example /start - Initialize bot /start /help - Show help /help /setkb <name\|url> Setup KB /setkb my-notes /kb - Show KB info /kb /status - Show statistics /status /settings - Settings menu /settings /viewsettings [category] View settings /viewsettings agent /setsetting <name> <value> Change setting /setsetting LOG_LEVEL DEBUG /resetsetting <name> Reset setting /resetsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT /kbsettings - KB settings /kbsettings /agentsettings - Agent settings /agentsettings

docs.title: Quick Configuration
docs.text: /settings → Choose category → Select setting → Change value

docs.title: Batch Changes
docs.text:
/setsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT 600
/setsetting KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH true
/setsetting LOG_LEVEL DEBUG

docs.title: View Before Change
docs.text:
/viewsettings agent
# Review current values
/setsetting AGENT_TYPE qwen_code_cli

docs.title: Reset All (Individual)
docs.text:
/resetsetting KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH
/resetsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT
/resetsetting MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Settings Management Guide
  • Working with Content
  • Knowledge Base Setup

docs.title: Knowledge Base Setup
docs.text: Setup and manage your knowledge base.

docs.title: Option 1: Local KB
docs.text:
mkdir my-kb
cd my-kb
git init
git commit --allow-empty -m "Initial commit"

Configure in config.yaml:

KB_PATH: ./my-kb
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: false

docs.title: Option 2: GitHub KB
docs.text:
1. Create repo on GitHub
  2. Clone locally
  3. Configure path
KB_PATH: ./my-kb
KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: true
KB_GIT_REMOTE: origin
KB_GIT_BRANCH: main

docs.title: KB Structure
docs.text:
knowledge_base/
├── topics/           # Categorized notes
│   ├── ai/
│   ├── biology/
│   ├── physics/
│   └── tech/
├── attachments/      # Media files
└── index.md          # KB index

docs.title: Git Integration
docs.text:
Enable Git operations:

KB_GIT_ENABLED: true
KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH: true

Every note is automatically: - Added to Git - Committed with message - Pushed to remote (if enabled)

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Bot Commands
  • Working with Content

docs.title: Settings Management
docs.text: Configure tg-note directly from Telegram.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The settings management system allows you to customize bot behavior without editing configuration files. All settings can be changed directly through Telegram commands.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• ✅ Interactive UI - Inline keyboards with category navigation
  • ✅ Type Safety - Automatic validation and conversion
  • ✅ Per-User - Each user has their own settings
  • ✅ Auto-Generated - New settings appear automatically
  • ✅ Secure - Credentials cannot be changed via Telegram

docs.title: Open Settings Menu
docs.text: /settings

docs.title: View All Settings
docs.text: /viewsettings

docs.title: Change a Setting
docs.text: /setsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT 600

docs.title: Reset to Default
docs.text: /resetsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT

docs.title: 📚 Knowledge Base
docs.text:
• KB_PATH - Path to knowledge base
  • KB_GIT_ENABLED - Enable Git operations
  • KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH - Auto-push changes
  • KB_GIT_REMOTE - Git remote name
  • KB_GIT_BRANCH - Git branch

docs.title: 🤖 Agent
docs.text:
• AGENT_TYPE - Agent implementation
  • AGENT_MODEL - AI model to use
  • AGENT_TIMEOUT - Operation timeout
  • AGENT_ENABLE_WEB_SEARCH - Enable web search
  • AGENT_ENABLE_GIT - Enable Git operations
  • AGENT_ENABLE_GITHUB - Enable GitHub API

docs.title: ⚙️ Processing
docs.text:
• MESSAGE_GROUP_TIMEOUT - Message grouping timeout
  • PROCESSED_LOG_PATH - Processing log path

docs.title: 📝 Logging
docs.text:
• LOG_LEVEL - Logging level (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR)
  • LOG_FILE - Log file path

docs.title: Interactive Menu
docs.text:
The /settings command provides:

  1. Category Selection - Browse by category
  2. Quick Toggles - One-tap for booleans
  3. Setting Details - View descriptions
  4. Reset Options - Restore defaults

docs.title: Change Timeout
docs.text: /setsetting AGENT_TIMEOUT 600

docs.title: Disable Auto-Push
docs.text: /setsetting KB_GIT_AUTO_PUSH false

docs.title: Enable Debug Logging
docs.text: /setsetting LOG_LEVEL DEBUG

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Bot Commands
  • Configuration Guide

docs.title: Working with Content
docs.text: Learn how to work with different types of content in tg-note.

docs.title: Supported Content Types
docs.text:
• ✅ Text messages
  • ✅ Forwarded messages from channels
  • ✅ Photos with captions
  • ✅ Documents
  • ✅ Links and URLs
  • ✅ Multiple consecutive messages

docs.title: Sending Text Messages
docs.text:
Simply send any text to save it:

This is an interesting article about AI...

The bot will: 1. Receive your message 2. Analyze the content 3. Categorize it 4. Save as Markdown 5. Commit to Git

docs.title: Forwarding Messages
docs.text:
Forward messages from any chat or channel:

  1. Find the message
  2. Tap Forward
  3. Select your tg-note bot

Works with: - Channel posts - Group messages - Media with captions - Links

docs.title: Sending Multiple Messages
docs.text:
Send consecutive messages for automatic grouping:

First message...
(wait)
Second message...
(wait)
Third message...

Messages sent within 30 seconds (configurable) are grouped into one note.

docs.title: Sending Links
docs.text:
Send article URLs:

https://arxiv.org/abs/12345

With Qwen Code CLI, the bot will: - Fetch the article - Analyze content - Extract key info - Save structured note

docs.title: Processing Workflow
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Content] --> B[Analysis]
    B --> C[Categorization]
    C --> D[Markdown]
    D --> E[Git Commit]
    E --> F[Notification]

docs.title: Output Structure
docs.text:
Your KB will have this structure:

knowledge_base/
├── topics/
│   ├── ai/
│   │   └── 2025-10-03-neural-networks.md
│   ├── biology/
│   │   └── 2025-10-03-crispr.md
│   └── physics/
│       └── 2025-10-03-quantum.md
└── index.md

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Bot Commands
  • Knowledge Base Setup
